extracted_determinations.text: :       DETERMINATION   [7] The panel finds that the claimants  have not satisfied the burden of establishing a serious  possibility of persecution for a Convention ground, or that they would personally be subjected, on a  balance of probabilities, to a danger of torture, or to a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unus ual  treatment or punishment.
Therefore, the panel finds that the claimants are neither Convention  refugees nor persons in need of protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the IRPA.

:       reliable and probative, it must also satisfy the Board, on a balance of probabilities, that state  protection is inadequate.9    [14]  In view of these principles, the panel finds that the claimants have not provided the requisite  clear and convincing evidence that, on a balance of probabilities, state protection in the Czech  Republic is inadequate.

The panel finds that the claimants, considering  their particular circumstances includ ing their education levels and sophistication , would have  recourse available upon return to the Czech Republic , if the police were to refuse to respond or if  the claimants were to  believe that their complaints were not being taken seriously.
If the claimants were to be denied protection upon return, the panel finds that the  claimants have legal redress  to address their complai nts.

[58]  Based on the totality of the evidence adduced, therefore, the panel finds that the claimants  have not satisfied the burden by providing clear and convincing evidence that, on a balan ce of  probabilities, adequate state protection would not be reasonably forthcoming if the claimants should  need it upon return.

Therefore, the panel finds that the claimants are neither Convention  refugees nor persons in need of protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the IRPA.

:       reliable and probative, it must also satisfy the Board, on a balance of probabilities, that state  protection is inadequate.9    [14]  In view of these principles, the panel finds that the claimants have not provided the requisite  clear and convincing evidence that, on a balance of probabilities, state protection in the Czech  Republic is inadequate.

[1] The claimants, [REDACTED] (the claimant) and his common -law partner , [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] (the female claimant), and their son , [REDACTED] (the minor -aged son) and daughter ,

[REDACTED] (the minor -aged daughter), all citizens of the Czech R epublic and the

Slovak Republic, seek refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and

Refugee Protection Act1 (the IRPA).

[2] The claimants’ identities as citizens of both the Czech Republic and the Slovak Republic

have been establi shed through their testimonies, documentation filed by the claimants,2 and

documents received from Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC).3

ALLEGATIONS

[3] The claimants allege that , as Roma , they will be discriminated against, harassed and even

harmed simpl y because of their race, in both the Slovak Republic and the Czech Republic.

[4] The claimants narrated several acts of discrimination against them and their family. For

example , they had to attend special schools. While living within the Czech community, th ey were

subject to threats including a threatening note attached to a rock that was thrown into their home

through a window in 2009 .

[5] Further details rega...

extracted_determinations.text: DETERMINATION [3] After considering the totality of the evi dence, the panel determines that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, pursuant to section 96 of the IRPA, nor is she a person in need of protection pursuant to section 97 of the IRPA.

The panel finds that the claimant has not est ablished that, on a balance of probability, her husband was targeted because of his political a ffiliation or that by extension she was targeted as his wife.
The panel determines that the claimant embellished her viva voce testimony and that there is no credible evidence anyone ever came looking for her husband.
It is natural to  try to find a reason behind a loved one’s death; however, the panel determines that the claimant  has failed to establish a link between her son’s death and grounds for protection.
The panel determines that the claimant’s behaviour of taking care of business matters is not in line with someone in hiding.

The panel finds that the claimant’s return to Nigeria for a month demonstrates a lack of subjective fear and that there is no credible evidence she was in hiding, if she went to resign from her work at the XXXXX.

expected_determinations: ["['claimant is not a person in need of protection']", "['negative']", "['claimant is not a convention refugee and not a person in need of protection', 'rejects the claim']"]

extra_determinations.text: DETERMINATION [3] After considering the totality of the evi dence, the panel determines that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, pursuant to section 96 of the IRPA, nor is she a person in need of protection pursuant to section 97 of the IRPA.

The panel finds that the claimant has not est ablished that, on a balance of probability, her husband was targeted because of his political a ffiliation or that by extension she was targeted as his wife.
The panel determines that the claimant embellished her viva voce testimony and that there is no credible evidence anyone ever came looking for her husband.
It is natural to  try to find a reason behind a loved one’s death; however, the panel determines that the claimant  has failed to establish a link between her son’s death and grounds for protection.
The panel determines that the claimant’s behaviour of taking care of business matters is not in line with someone in hiding.

The panel finds that the claimant’s return to Nigeria for a month demonstrates a lack of subjective fear and that there is no credible evidence she was in hiding, if she went to resign from her work at the XXXXX.

[1] [REDACTED], a citizen of the Federal Republic of Nigeria (hereinafter referred to as Nigeria), claims refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

1 ALLEGATIONS [2] The claimant alleges the following. The claimant met her husband, [REDACTED] in 1983 and married him in 1987. She had four children with her husband. Her husband became involved in politics in 19XX and became a member of the Democratic Alternative Party (DAP). The “community” mostly supported the Advance Party. In March 2004, the claimant’s “community” in [REDACTED] was in turmoil because of the elections. The claimant alleges that her husband disappear ed in 2004 after being accused of killing a well-known member of the community. The claimant felt threatened and left Nigeria for England in [REDACTED] 2004. The children of the claimant remained in Nigeria with her sister and attended school. The claimant returned to Nigeria in 20XXbecause her son died of food poisoning and returned to England after a m onth. The claimant did not claim asylum in the United Kingdom (UK) during her three years of residency and on May 21, 2007 entered Canada with a false passport. Once her false passport was detected by the Canadian official at the air...

extracted_determinations.text: Having considered the totality of the evid ence, the panel finds that the claimant has not rebutted the presumption of state prot ection and is not a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.
The panel finds that the claimant did not make any dilige nt or bona fide attempt to seek protection in his country of origin before travelling abroad for asylum.

After careful consideration of all the evid ence and because of the reasons set out above, the panel finds that the claimant doe s not have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of any of the enumerated grounds.
The panel therefore finds that the claimant is not a Convention refugee.

Having found that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, the panel also considered the applicability of sections 97(1)(a ) and 97(1)(b) of the Act, and finds that no evidence was adduced that would support a finding that the claimant faces a danger of torture.

2005 CanLII 77802 (CA IRB) TA4-16824    13 CONCLUSION  For these reasons, the Refugee Protection Di vision determines that the claimant is not a Convention refugee nor is he a person in need of protection and therefore, rejects his claim for refugee protection.

2005 CanLII 77802 (CA IRB)



TA4-16824 These are the reasons for the negative decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) with respect to the claim of [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the claimant), a 23-year-old citizen of Mexico.

1 The hearing for this claim was held pursuant to subsection 170(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

2 (IRPA). The claimant alleged that he has a well-found ed fear of persecution if he were to return to Mexico by reason of his sexual orientation. In addition, he claims to be a person in need of protection by reason of either, a danger of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture or to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. ISSUES AND DETERMINATION

The determinative issue in this claim is whether the claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution in Mexico by reason of a Convention ground, including whether the claimant has rebutted the presumption of state protection. Having considered the totality of the evid ence, the panel finds that the claimant has not rebutted the presumption of state prot ection and is not a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.



1 Exhibit R/A-2, certified true copy of the claimant’s Mexican passport.

2 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. 2001, c. 27.

2005 CanLII 77802 (CA IRB)

TA4-16824

2 ALLEGATIONS

The claimant’s testimony of past events going to the basis of his fear is contained in his narrativ...

extracted_determinations.text: Based on the lack of credibility of the documents, the Panel finds that the claimant has failed to establish the issue of affiliation surrounding her membership in the AEUP.

Based on th e claimant’s failure to claim for refugee protection in Japan and her delay in departing Ethiopia from the time of the commencement of the alleged fear, the Panel finds that the claimant has failed to establish the element of subjective fear.
The Panel finds that the claimant  was not an active member of the AEUP or the CUD, and that the events related to he r alleged membership and political involvement did not occur.
Therefore, the Panel conc ludes that the claimant is not a Convention refugee.

Since the Panel concludes that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX has not suffered serious harm while in Ethiopia and that she does not face a serious possibility of serious harm should she return to that country, the Panel concludes that the claimant is not a person in need of protection pursuant to section 97(1)(a) and (b) of the IRPA, as there is no risk to her life, or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture, upon returning to Ethiopia.

2006 CanLII 61233 (CA IRB) TA5-13270     10 Conclusion  The Panel determines that the claimant  is not a Convention refugee and not a person in need of protection in accordance with sections 96 and 97(1)(a) and (b) of the IRPA.

expected_determinations: ["['claimant is not a convention refugee and not a person in need of protection']", "['claimant is not a convention refugee']", "['negative']"]

The Panel finds that the claimant  was not an active member of the AEUP or the CUD, and that the events related to he r alleged membership and political involvement did not occur.
Therefore, the Panel conc ludes that the claimant is not a Convention refugee.

Since the Panel concludes that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX has not suffered serious harm while in Ethiopia and that she does not face a serious possibility of serious harm should she return to that country, the Panel concludes that the claimant is not a person in need of protection pursuant to section 97(1)(a) and (b) of the IRPA, as there is no risk to her life, or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture, upon returning to Ethiopia.

2006 CanLII 61233 (CA IRB) TA5-13270     10 Conclusion  The Panel determines that the claimant  is not a Convention refugee and not a person in need of protection in accordance with sections 96 and 97(1)(a) and (b) of the IRPA.

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED], a citizen of Ethiopia,

1 claims Convention refugee status by reason of her political opinion. The claimant claims that due to her participation in the All Ethiopian Unity Party (AEUP) and the Coalition for Unity and Democracy (CUD), also known as KINIJIT, she is be ing targeted by the Ethiopian police and government security forces. She is also claiming that she is a person in need of protection in accordance with section 97(1)(a) and (b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA). Claimant’s Allegations The claimant is a professional [REDACTED]. She was hired by a Japanese company to work and compete as a [REDACTED] in Japan from [REDACTED] 2004 until [REDACTED] 2005. The claimant returned to Ethiopian at the conclusion of her employment with the Japanese company. The claimant was a member of the AEUP and, prior to going to Japan, her participation was limited to attending two pa rty meetings. Upon her return from Japan and prior to the election of May 2005, sh e attended two meetings of the CUD and contributed money to the party.

2



1 Exhibit R-2, Information received from Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC), includes an Ethiopian passport and Birth Certificate for the claimant.

2 Exhibit C-1, Personal Information Form (PIF), question 31, p. 1.

2006 CanLII 61233 (CA IRB)

TA5-13270

extracted_determinations.text: 2005 CanLII 60037 (CA IRB) TA4-04286    2Having considered the totality of the evid ence, the panel finds that the claimant has not rebutted the presumption of state prot ection and is neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.

The panel finds that the claimant did not make any diligent or bona fide attempt to seek protection in her country of origin regarding the attack by her sister, the threats by her brother or the alleged attack by the two men on her boyfriend before travelling abroad for asylum.

After careful consideration of all the evid ence and because of the reasons set out above, the panel finds that the claimant doe s not have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of any of the enumerated grounds.
Given that the panel finds that adequate state protection would be available to the cl aimant in Poland, the panel therefore finds that the claimant is not a Convention refugee.

Having found that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, the panel also considered the applicability of sections 97(1)(a ) and 97(1)(b) of the Act, and finds that no evidence was adduced that would support a finding that the claimant faces a danger of torture.

2005 CanLII 60037 (CA IRB) TA4-04286    12 CONCLUSION  For these reasons, the Refugee Protection Di vision determines that the claimant is not a Convention refugee nor is she a person in  need of protection and therefore, rejects her claim for refugee protection.

TA4-04286 These are the reasons for the negative decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) with respect to the claim of [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the claimant), a 24-year-old citizen of Poland.

1 The hearing for this claim was held pursuant to subsection 170(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

2 (IRPA). The claimant alleged that she has a well-found ed fear of persecution if she were to return to Poland by reason of her membership in a particular social group, that is, a person who has been targeted by family member s because of her desire to marry a man of another faith. In addition, she claims to be a person in need of protection by reason of either a danger of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture or to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. At the hearing, the claimant’s husband [REDACTED] was called as a witness in support of the claimant. ISSUES AND DETERMINATION

The determinative issue in this claim is whether the claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution in Poland by reason of a Convention ground including whether the claimant has rebutted the presumption of state protection.



1 Exhibit R/A-2, information provided by Citizensh ip and Immigration Canada (CIC), certified true copy of the claimant’s Polish passport.

2 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. 2001, c. 27.

These are the reasons with respect to the claim made by [REDACTED] [REDACTED] to be a Convention refugee and a person in need of protection. The claimant is a 42-year-old married, male citizen of the People’s Republic of China (hereinafter referred to as China). The claimant fears returning to China due to his involvement in an underground Christian church. Allegations The claimant was a long distance truck dr iver in China. In mid- [REDACTED] 2004, the claimant’s partner and he transported goods to [REDACTED] at night. When they were on a slope he could not slow down the truck because something went wrong with the brakes. The claimant was in a panic and at this crucial time his partner murmured, which he could hear clearly. The claimant was angry with him because he seemed not to worry as he tried his best to stop the truck, and finall y he turned the wheel to the rock close to the hill and the truck stopped. After the truck stopped, the claimant’s pa rtner said, “Thank God.” The claimant was very curious why he did not worry and hi s partner told him that he was praying to God for help and God protected them. He also said that he was a Christian and talked to the claimant about God, who is almighty. When they were off work, his friend, [REDACTED], came to him and talked to him about his religion and God’s love, as well as some stories about [REDACTED]. Th...

extracted_determinations.text: DETERMINA TION   [13]  The  Panel  finds that the claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXX , is not a Convention refugee  pursuant to s.
:     Persona l Identity and Credibility   [15]  The  Panel  finds that the claimant has not established his personal or national identity.
Political Identity  and Cre dibility   [18]  The Panel  finds that the claimant has not established his political identity.

The Panel  gives no evidentiary weight to the card given  that it has no security features, there is no envelope, and the Panel  finds that the claimant’s  testimony regarding the issuance of the card to be not credible.
[22]  The Panel  finds  that the claimant provided no trustworthy original identity  documents.
Thus, the Panel  finds that the  claimant has not  discharged the burden of establishing  his identity  as set out in section 106 of the IRPA .

[1] [REDACTED] seeks refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the

Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA )1.

Allegations

[2] The claimant alleges the following.

[3] He was born on [REDACTED] , 19XX in [REDACTED] , Uganda. He has never married.

[4] The claimant joined the Forum for Democratic Change (FDC), the major opposition

political party, in [REDACTED] 2005. In [REDACTED] 2009 he was elected to the position of XX XX [REDACTED]

in his constituency. Between 2 005 and 2006 the claimant was arrested and detained about [REDACTED]

times for participating in demonstrations against the National Resistance Movement (NRM), the

political party in power.

[5] The claimant was very active in the run up to the February 18, 2011 elec tion. NRM cadre

subjected him to various forms of intimidation, harassment and threats. On April 11, 2011 a

number of opposition members of parliament were arrested and charged. On [REDACTED] , 2011 the

claimant took part in a protest against these arrests. During the protest he was arrested and detained

at [REDACTED] in [REDACTED] . He was brutally tortured and accused of trying to overthrow the

government. He was released on [REDACTED] , 2011 with a warning that if he were caught again he

would be killed. On [REDACTED] , 20 11 the claimant received a telephone c...

extracted_determinations.text: The panel finds that the claimant has fabricated his story about being targeted by PAN for th e purpose of his refugee protection claim.
The panel finds that the claimant has fabricated his story about XXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXX and being targeted as a result.

Based on the totality of the evidence adduced, because of a number of credibility issues, the panel finds that the claimant’s evidence is not  credible or trustworthy in areas central and material to his claim.
The panel finds that the claimant has not met the burden of establishing “clear and convincing” proof of a lack of state protection for individuals like him in Mexico.

Therefore, the panel finds that the claimant, living in a democracy, simply did not reasonably exhaust any course of  action open to him in obtaining state protection in Mexico, and, therefore, he has not discharged  the onus of showing clear and convincing proof of the state’s inability or unwillingness to protect him.

extracted_determinations.text: The panel finds that the claimant has not rebutted the presumption of state protection and she is not a Convention refugee, as she does not have a well-founded f ear of persecution for a Convention ground in Hungary.

Having considered the totality of the evid ence the panel finds that the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that her removal to Hungary would not subject her personally to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unus ual treatment or punishment, and that there are no substantial grounds to believe that her remova l to Hungary will subject her personally to a danger of torture.
The panel finds that the claimant did not report any of the incidents of domestic violence to the authorities in Hungary.

After careful cons ideration of all the evidence and because of the reasons set out above, the panel finds that the claimant does not have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of any of the enumerated gr ounds.
Given that the panel finds that adequate state protection would be available to the claimant in Hungary the panel therefore finds that the claimant is not a Convention refugee.

/ N° de dossier de la SPR :  TA6-13204   10  CONCLUSION  For these reasons, the Refugee Protection Divisi on determines that the claimant is not a Convention refugee nor is she a person in need of  protection and therefore, rejects her claim for refugee protection.

hese are the reasons for the negative decisi on of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) with respect to the claim of [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the claimant), a 29 year-old citizen of Hungary.

1 The claimant claims protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

2 The claimant alleged that she has a well-founded fear of persecution if she were to return to Hungary by reason of her membership in a pa rticular social group, that is, a woman who has been subjected to domestic violence. In addition, sh e claims to be a person in need of protection. Counsel’s written submissions received Marc h 18, 2008 were taken into consideration before the panel rendered its decision. ISSUES AND DETERMINATION

1



REASONS FOR DECISION

Introduction and Issue

[1] This is an appeal pursuant to section 63( 2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection

Act1 (IRPA ) of a removal order b ased on IRPA s. 40(1)(a) made against the appellant .

[2] The appellant does not contest the validity of the officer’s decision ; the issue is w hether

the appellant has proven that there are grounds to warrant special relief.

Decision

[3] Having considered the evide nce and submissions, the panel finds that the exclusion order

is valid and that the appellant has proven on a balance of probabilities that the appeal warrants

special relief. The appeal is allowed .

Background

[4] The Immigration Division held an Admissibility Hearing and on March 16 , 20 09 issued

an Exclusion Order against the appellant ,2 with reasons,3 based on withholding information

concerning h is marriage. The appellant appeals from that Order.4

[5] The appellant testified and filed four exhibit s of documentary evidence ; his girlfriend also

testified. The respondent filed one exhibit , consisting of th...

extracted_determinations.text: (1) To allow an appeal, the Immigration Appeal Divisi on must be satisfied  that, at the time that the appeal is disposed of,   (a) the decision appealed is wrong in law or fact or mixed law and fact;   (b) a principle of natural justice has not been observed; or   (c) other than in the case of an appeal by the Mini ster, taking into account the  best interests of a child directly affected by the decision, sufficient  humanitarian and compassionate considerations warrant special relief in light   of all the circumstances of the case.
The  appeal is allowed .

In a case  where the appellant's changed financial circumstances bring him above the Low   Income Cut -Off over the 12 months preceding the date of hearing, but the  appellant is otherwise unsympathetic, the appropriate response of the Appeal  Division might well be to dismiss the appeal, leaving a new sponsorship as the  only option for the appell ant.
[26]  The respondent is correct that there is little or no hardship that would attach to dismissing  the appeal.
XXXXXXX had going for him was that he was hard working and he l oved his parents , but his appeal  was allowed on these factors ; that is , pure family reunification.
[32]  The appeal is allowed.

REASONS FOR DECISION



[1] The appellant, [REDACTED], appeals from the refusal to grant a permanent resident

visa to his mother [REDACTED] (the applicant) from Vietnam. The applicant was denied a

visa because a visa officer at the High Commission of Canada in Singapore determined that her

sponsor, the appellant, did not have sufficient income to satisfy the Minimum Necessary Income

(MNI) under section 133(1)(j)(i) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (the

Regulations ).



[2] The appellant is a citizen of Canada who became permanent resident of Canada in April

1990. The appellant was born in Vietnam in 1961 and when he was six years old his father died

and it was left to his mother, the applicant, to raise him and his two older sisters. The appellant

testified at his hearing on May 31, 2013 that he had the best mother, who laboured in the rice

fields, but despite her efforts the family was very poor. The appe llant testified that in 1986 he

was separated from his family when he, along with others, fled the hardship in Vietnam for the

relative security of life in Cambodia a...

Reasons for Decision



INTRODUCTION



[1] These are the reasons for the decision of an Oral Reconsideration of a two -year stay of

removal granted to Mort[REDACTED] (the appellant) by Immigration Appeal

Division (IAD) Member [REDACTED]. The stay of removal was extended a further three -

year term by Member [REDACTED] on December 19, 2008 . The stay of removal was also

reviewed and continued by Member [REDACTED] on July 28, 2010.



[2] This oral review comes as a result of an application made by the Canadian Border

Services Agency (CBSA) on the basis that the appellan t had breached his stay, by not havin g

complied with conditions [11 ] and [16] of his stay of removal. Condition [11] required the

appellant to attend an alcohol rehabilitation program at the Scarborough Hospital Community

Mental Health Addiction Program or Alcoholics Anonymous and provide written evidence of

enrolment and attendance by December 17, 2010. Condition [16] required the appellant to pay

back any outstanding fines or at least provide evidence of payments being made pursuant to a

payment agreement.

April 16, 2007 Toronto, Ontario

April 16, 2007

Raja Kanagarayar (a.k.a. Kanagara)

Minister’s Counsel Conseil de l’intimé



2007 CanLII 67372 (CA IRB)

IAD File No. /Dossier : TA5-05130 1

Oral Reasons for Decision

Introduction [1] These are the reasons in the appeal, pursuan t to subsection 63(4) of the Immigration and

Refugee Protection Act (IRPA ) of Vama[REDACTED] (the appellant). He is appealing the visa officer’s determination that he is in breach of his residency obligation. [2] On March 10, 2005, a visa officer determined that the appellant had failed to comply with the residency obligations set out in section 28 of IRPA

. As a result, the appellant was found to be inadmissible to Canada pursuant to subsection 41(b) of IRPA

. The officer also found that the appellant had not satisfied the requirement s of paragraphs 31(3)(a) and (b) of IRPA

, and therefore, his application for a travel document was refused. [3] Specifically, the appellant had failed to reside in Canada for at least 730 days in the five years preceding the date of his application, that is, from March 10, 2000 to March 10, 2005. The officer was also not satisfied, pursu ant to paragraph 28(2)(c) of IRPA,

that sufficient and humanitarian and compassionate considerations, ta king into account the best interest of a child directly affected of the determination, justified retention of permanent residence status ...
